data.text: Are Flat Pedals a Good Idea for a Bikepacking Bike?

I'm building up my bikepacking bike was thinking about trying flat pedals. I imagine it's a personal preference thing but any recommendations? I've been using relatively cheap Shimano M424s for 20+ years and have been happy with them but thought I'd try some flats. I can't believe how expensive some of the flat pedal are though, wow! Thanks

Anything with a good number of replaceable pins and reliable bearings will be good. There are tons of composite options for $40-50, and nicer aluminum ones start to run closer to $100. I really like the shape of Issi's flat pedals, myself.
data.author: Chris Roach

data.text: I have the large Aluminum Issi pedals on my Bridge Club. They work well with 12 wide feet.

data.text:
Does anyone have experience with Yoshimura Cycling pedals? The look nice and I like that they're made here in California, but they're quite a bit more expensive. Maybe I should try some cheaper flats before dropping that kind of money? https://yoshimuracycling.com/collections/pedals/products/chilao-performance-bicycle-pedal
CHILAO LARGE PEDALS IN PEWTER
yoshimuracycling.com
data.author: Eric Green

data.text:
Look at it this way. A quality pedal like the Yoshimura‚Äôs will likely last you a lifetime and offer you piece of mind that they‚Äôre not going to fail or cause you any trouble, especially while you‚Äôre in the midst of a bikepacking adventure. I also really like the Shimano Saint flat pedals. I have two pairs of the first generation ones. They‚Äôre probably 15+ years old and have been absolutely trouble free. Or if you‚Äôre not looking to spend a whole lot on intro to flats, I think these by PNW will be thought to beat, especially for the price. They‚Äôre also fully serviceable and rebuildable too and that‚Äôs not something you see on very many pedals in this price range. https://bikepacking.com/news/check-out-the-new-pnw-range-pedal/
Check out the new PNW Range Pedal
bikepacking.com

data.text: , great info, thanks! I hate the idea of buying something disposable but at least these pedals are rebuildable.

data.text: I use MBR V12‚Äôs, have used the V8‚Äôs in the past, good pedals and easy to service.

data.text: I had some cheap Nashbar combo pedals on my single speed, I liked the versatility. I just bought a new touring bike, I outfitted with SHIMANO PD-M324 SPD Dual Platform Pedals. Nice pedals, same versatility. I use primarily Shimano sandals when I ride, but I like being able to wear flipflops for a short ride.
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: So there's a lot of good ones out there. I have Race Face Atlas and they're extremely good. Very low profile very good bearings, very wide platform. However I am considering shaving off the or out removing the pins...they catch my shins and calves too often....and the problem is that if you just look at them wrong, they'll gouge you!
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: A counter viewpoint to this one. I love the aggressive pins on my flat pedals. They grip my shoes/saddles and give me control and power for about 75% of the stroke. Icna focus power on pulling through the bottom or pushing over the top. I bought less expensive pedals till I found d the style ( wide platform aggressive pins ) that suits me, then I dropped $90 into a good set when I wore out the cheep set.
data.author: Al Christensen

data.text: , it might be the new 2022 Atlas pedals that come with a bunch of small washers to allow adjustment of pin length. I looked at a lot of pedals yesterday so it might have been a different pedal.
data.author: Eric Green

data.text: Yeah I just haven't good luck with the pedals more so when I'm off the bike. While on the bike I agree, very grippy....just tired of all the cuts and gashes from flat pedals going back all the way to my BMX days...I will normally wear my spd's and just have a pair of shoes when I'm off the bike for a while.

data.text: Flats all day...Bikepacking requires a lot of hike-a-bike in the best situations, so good hiking shoes will make this experience so much more enjoyable than some SPD specific shoes...100%
data.author: Vincent Peragine

data.text: Worth buying a good quality pedal.... I also like to be able to adjust feet position when things start getting numb or uncomfortable... Also the added bonus of wearing flip flops on hot days... Priceless
data.author: Vincent Peragine

data.text: So. . .just try flats. You will either like it or not. You'll still enjoy the ride. Get off FB and ride your bike FFS.

data.text: I use Flats after decades of other pedals. I do mostly touring these days and like the freedom of flats and think the advantage of other pedals is overstated. Just try it.Ôøº You can buy good light pedals for between $20 and $60Ôøº.

data.text: Have a look at DMR Vaults in Nylon, they are light and warmer underfoot than metal in winter. I am also a 25yr SPD convert to flats in the last 6 months. Still looking for some summer footwear that's Bikepacking friendly and not too clumpy, can't stand big heavy shoes.

data.author: John McAndrew

data.text: I did a ton of research and ended up with Spank Spoon 100's (not the DC version). You can get larger or smaller sizes of these pedals (110's, 100's, 90's), and you can also replace the pins with a smaller 7mm size if you want. The 100's are great for my size 9 shoe but could accomodate larger. I am not missing clipless shoes/pedals at all and like the flexibility of a flat pedal/flat pedal shoes for bikepacking/touring. They are thin, mildly concave, a good weight, and feel terrific under foot. You can spend more money and get fancier pedals, but these are well priced right now through Amazon. Found them for $69 in black with some digging around.
data.author: Hope W. Martin
